name: Iconography
htmlBanner:
Icon

The key goal of our entire visual system is to present information as clearly as possible. Well-executed typography that works within the system creates harmony and balance.

Overview.html:
Principles

Product icons are derived from basic geometric shapes and created using a consistent grid system to deliver a unified look and feel.

Geometry

We use simple, modern and approachable geometric shapes.

Stroke

We use a bold and precise stroke to reflect connections and emphasize ideas.

Roundness

We use friendly, rounded corners for a distinct look and feel.

Colors

The Momentum icons are created with a decisive balance of size, shape, and weight in place. Adding color to the set should be carefully considered and very intentional.

Use of color should be used to communicate further information to the user. Do not use gradients or colors other than the ones below for icons.

White and black

Generally, icons should be either white or black depending on the UI theme. Color should be used sparingly.

ÙÄãâ

Flag icon: White (left) and Black (right)

Approved colors

We use text tokens in the Theme Token library for our icons. There are 5 colors that can be used: normal, affirmative, negative, warning, and accent.

Document-create: Normal, Affirmative, Negative, Warning, Accent

Active states

The filled weight is used to communicate that an icon is active. Sometimes that is not enough and the ‚Äúaccent‚Äù color can be used.

Pen icon: Active and Accent color

Types, weights, and sizes

The Momentum icons are created with a decisive balance of size, shape, and weight in place. Adding color to the set should be carefully considered and very intentional.

Use of color should be used to communicate further information to the user. Do not use gradients or colors other than the ones below for icons.

Momentum vs SF Symbol

In order to align with iconography on iOS native applications, we have included the SF Symbol variant on iconography using the SF Symbol rather than the custom Momentum icon.

Flag-circle icon: Momentum (left) and SF Symbol (right)

Weights

Our Iconography System is based on three different weights plus filled shapes. Primarily, we use the bold weight in our UIs.

Content-download icon: light, regular, bold, filled

Sizes

Icons are scalable, however they should align to a 4px grid. If paired with type, they use the same size as the type.
16px and 24px are the most commonly used icon sizes across our components.

Fulfillment icon: 12px, 16px, 24px, 32px, 64px

Variations

Modifiers

Some icons will be part of a set of similar icons containing modifiers. These can be used to communicate additional information or features.

Folder icon with variants, schedule icon with variants, email icon with variants.

Letter in icons

While we do have several icons in our library that utilize letters, this is a bad practice and easily fails accessibility and localization best practices.
Please do not request such icons.

From left to right: word, gif, closed-caption-badge, closed-captions.

Using icons

In components

We use placeholder icons in our components. When you see this icon, you should feel free to click into it and replace it with the icon that you need.

Icon-button and pill-button

Interactive icons

Icons can be used outside the context of icon-buttons. These are small (20px) and usually used as a close button or an overflow menu inside a larger component.

Example of interactive icons: rest, hover, press, active, disabled, and focus states.

Pairing text and icons

Icons freely paired with typography should match the typography‚Äôs line height. Line height of the type can be found in the type tokens.

Icon size should match the typography‚Äôs line height.

How To Use.html:
How to enable Token Library

Step 1.

Access the ‚ÄòTeam library‚Äô modal by clicking the Library icon.

Step 2.

Navigate to the ‚ÄòWebex Suite Apps‚Äô tab to browse available shared libraries.

Step 3.

Find applicable theme libraries (üíé Theme - Dark / üíé Theme - Light UI) and click ‚ÄòAdd to file‚Äù button. Once enabled, the button will appear as ‚Äò‚úîÔ∏èAdded‚Äô.

How to Apply Theme Tokens

Step 1.

Select the element that you‚Äôd like to apply color tokens.

Step 2.

Search a style icon to reveal list of color tokens.

Step 3.

Search a token by typing the sentiment or usage of the element. Then click it to apply.

Step 4.

Once applied, you will see the mapped tokens.

How to Swap Themes

Step 1.

Click library icon to open the library modal.

Step 2.

View a list of all libraries which have styles and components used in your file

Step 3.

Click Swap library

Step 4.

Use the Choose library field

Step 5.

You will see all matching color style and effects with the box next to the asset is checked. If no matching styles or components are found, the box is unchecked and you'll see a None found message.

Step 6.

Click Swap library to replace the theme from your selected token library. Note that library swap would override every instance in your file, so leave unchecked the colors that you‚Äôd like to preserve.

How To Read.html:
Token Naming Structure

Knowing how to read token names will make it easier for you to find the right token when you're working on designs or code. The name of a design token describes its usage, and each part of the name tells you something about how it's meant to be used.

  • Sentiment.Usage.Fixed (Optional).Prominence (Optional).Interaction (Optional)

Sentiment

Sentiment indicates the meaning or role of the color. By using it, designers and developers can reduce the superstition about color design and systematically manage color.

Usage

Usage refers to where the token is applied in the UI, whether it's a background, text, border, or another property.

Based on where component sit on, we broke down usage into 4 categories: background, surface, content, and border.

Background

Background tokens are used for the main app background and content area.

Desktop & Web OX

Mobile (iOS)

Surface

Surfaces define container areas

Unlike other sentiment colors, the neutral palette comprises four surfaces designated by their roles: primary, secondary, tertiary, and overlay.

Primary

Used for containers that sit on the 2nd column.

Secondary

Used for containers that sit on the content area and global search.

Tertiary

Used for components which appears in a layer above other content; dialog, toast, menu, pop-over.

Overlay

Used for backdrop or overlay effect.

Content

Content refer on-surface instances like text (icons), buttons, controls, indicators (tags, labels, presence, avatars), and illustrations. Each element employs appropriate tokens.

Text/Icon
Button
Control
Indicator
Illustration

Border

Border tokens are applied to outlines of component and dividers.

Prominence

Prominence indicates the visual hierarchy, highlighting how much an element stands out visually. It emphasizes the contrast a color has against the background.

Momentum incorporates three ordinal scales for element prominence. Please note that prominence is optional and can be excluded if not needed.

Importance

primary

secondary

tertiary

  • Used when elements have a clear hierarchy in between.
  • Used for background, text, surface, and buttons.
Strength

strong

bold

default

moderate

subtle

  • Range from weak to strongest.
  • Used for borders.
  • Default passes minimum AA contrast requirement.
Numeric

0

1

2

3

4

  • Used when no relation or no-hirearchy in between elements.
  • Used for surfaces (tertiary, overlay), illustrations

Interaction

Interaction

Focus Effect

There is no dedicated token for Focus State. Instead, select the Focus Effect to components once the theme token library is enabled.

For full transparency surfaces, add a 0.01% white/black fill (#FFFFFF in dark/#000000 in light)to components. Make sure to check "Clip content" in design panel.

Color Tokens.html:
What are Color Tokens?

Color Tokens are the single source of truth for all colors used in Webex Brand.

With color tokens, our visual language evolves, changes can be made once across the system and products. This will deliver visual consistency and help applying colors in a reusable, and scalable way.

Types of Color Tokens

Currently, Momentum uses two tiers of tokens to manage color. In most cases, designers are only allowed to use Alias Tokens instead of applying Core Tokens directly.

Color Tokens

Core color token is our color foundation that used in product UI. They are primitive values that does not have any associated explicit meaning or intent, and only used to be referenced for theme tokens. üîó Core Token Librar

Alias Token (a.k.a Theme Token)

Alias Tokens (aka. Theme Tokens) are context-specific and reference core color tokens. They are built using semantic names that help provide an understanding on how or when the token should be used. Note that all components should be applied to Theme Tokens. üîó Theme Token Library (Dark)‚Ä®�� Theme Token Library (Ligh

How to Access

Additional ways to access color token libraries for designers and engineers.

In Figma

All tokens used in Momentum are in 04 - üíé Tokens under _Momentum Design System. To use token in your working file, you need to enable the respective token file by accessing the Team Libraries

üîó All Token libraries‚Ä®�� How to enable librari

For Engineering

On the engineering side, we use the Momentum Design mono-repository

üîó Momentum Design Repository‚Ä®�� Token NPM Packa

How to Request Tokens

You may need to request a new color token or report a bug in the token library. Regarding all of these changes, we receive change requests through the Momentum Request Form

Tickets are reviewed and handled by the Momentum team in a 3-week sprint cycle.

Color.html:
Overview

Momentum colors integrate seamlessly, like the connections that Webex enables. We use color to add life, energy, and personality to our experiences.

Color Principles

Vibrant

Our colors expresses of energy and synergy through uplifting shades and dynamic gradients.

Consistent

Our color system supports a uniform visual appearance across diverse products and platforms.s.

Accessible

Our color system ensures an adequate contrast ratio and strives to adhere to Web Content Accessibility Guidelines whenever feasible.

Momentum Color Anatomy

The application of the color palette ensures a unified and easily recognizable consistency across Webex's extensive range of products and interfaces. This consistency is maintained through a set of guidelines on working with the component library within the context of both dark and light themes.

Neutral

Our key color palette consists of a Black & White, and gray foundation. They don‚Äôt typically have a meaning associated with them, though they can imply things like disabled states. They apply to most backgrounds, text, and shapes in our experiences.

Black and white have varying levels of alpha-value. These transparency enable to create seamless, fluid layouts

Semantic

Semantic refers to the significance or purpose of a color. By employing this approach, designers and developers can dispel misconceptions about color design and methodically oversee color usage.

In conjunction with the primary blue accent, we have several semantic colors, each serving a distinct purpose within the UI.

Decorative

Decorative color palette extends our brand color expression. The accent tones are digitally native, intentionally bright and rich in contrast.

Mostly used for aesthetic purpose in indicators, avatar, teams, and data visualizations. These colors are less strict on WCAG 2.1 and are not to be used for typical UI designs.

Applying Color

All the colors used in our UIs are designed to pass the WCAG AA requirements

When choosing colors, the tint between 50-60 is safe to use for non-text elements. For text elements, use up to <40 on dark, and down to >70 on light backgrounds

Theming

Theming represents our inclusivity. We support the individuality and uniqueness of our users through customizations - themable interfaces and background image choices.

Default Dark and Light theme
Additional Themes
